text:
Anywaysi think we can define matrix multiplication on the boolean semiring.
And just as conventional matrix powers applies to adjacency matrxes tell us number of walks between vertexes identified by row and column.
The boolean semiring matmul's powers should just tell us if there is a path connecting or not.
And *should* be much cheaper to compute

text: There was actually a stack overflow question about that last month <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64939193/boolean-matrix-multiplication-in-julia>

attachments.title: Boolean matrix multiplication in Julia
attachments.text: I need to multiply two boolean matrices in Julia. Doing simply A*A or A^2 returns an Int64 Matrix. Is there a way how to multiply efficiently boolean matrices?
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: Boolean matrix multiplication in Julia

elements.text: There was actually a stack overflow question about that last month

text: There's a similar theorem in the more general setting of the max-plus algebra on the real numbers that states that the kleene star (summing the powers of a matrix) of a weighted adjacency matrix computes the weights of the shortest paths between all pairs of vertice.
